comments.author: tomasz1986
comments.body:
> I am worried there is an over reliance on ARIA where native controls and functions could be used, such as, the below for example regarding links.

The general rule is that if you have to use things like `role=img`, then this likely means that the element itself should just be a simple `img` (and not `div` or similar). You can find this ARIA overuse on many websites with `<nav role="navigation>`, which is completely useless and only adds bloat.

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
> I genuinely do not think links need an ARIALABEL if link text/titles are descriptive enough.

Thank you for the feedback!

There are cases where links/buttons in Joplin have no text content but have a `title` attribute. According [to `w3.org`](https://www.w3.org/WAI/tutorials/forms/labels/#using-the-title-attribute),
> The title attribute can also be used to identify form controls. This approach is generally less reliable and not recommended because some screen readers and assistive technologies do not interpret the title attribute as a replacement for the label element, possibly because the title attribute is often used to provide non-essential information.

Based on this, `aria-label` is being added in some cases where a button/link has no text content, even if it already has a `title`.

**Related links**:
- [Advisory technique: Describing a link's purpose with aria-label](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/aria/ARIA8.html)
- [How different screen readers interpret link + title and link + aria-label](https://www.deque.com/blog/text-links-practices-screen-readers/)


> If I knew what the mobile apps and desktop apps were made in, I could better advise but this is a great start!

The desktop app is built with Electron and React. The mobile app is built with React Native.

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
> The general rule is that if you have to use things like role=img, then this likely means that the element itself should just be a simple img (and not div or similar).

Thank you for the feedback!

Currently, Joplin **does** use `role="img"` for its font icons. For example, Joplin uses FontAwesome `<i>` webfont icons. For this type of icon, [ARIA 24](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/aria/ARIA24.html) recommends:
> Some low vision users need user stylesheets, scripts, or extensions to override the fonts on a page to perceive text content. However, they need to be able to perceive icon fonts that are meaningful, such as a star signifying a favorite, or an email icon in a link.
>
> The key is for the author to semantically markup icon fonts with role="img". Then the user's font replacement selector can hook into that semantic and exclude role="img". This results in those icon fonts being shown.

An alternative to webfont+`role=img` could be to use SVG icons (e.g. with [FontAwesome SVG](https://docs.fontawesome.com/web/dig-deeper/webfont-vs-svg)). However, this would likely require significant code changes.

comments.author: tomasz1986
comments.body: Yeah, icon fonts are not good for accessibility since they are basically a hack to display images instead of text (as should be expected with fonts normally), so they have issues with screen readers, and they also cause problems when the user wants (or needs due to a particular disability) to use their own font for the whole application or website. SVG icons are much better in this aspect, but as you've said, implementing them would require a major rewrite of the code ðŸ™.

comments.body: > [ðŸ”Ž] How can we make it easy for users to add alternative text to videos and audio elements? **[Suggest close]** When attaching a video, it puts the filename as the title, eg `[myvideo.mp4](:/5ca9d953c01643d6a503b473c1e92a2d)`. Then in the renderer this is used for the link `title` attribute and for the content: `myvideo.mp4`. Isn't it sufficient? Beyond this, I believe it is not the app responsability to make the user content accessible - they have the option to give detailed description in the title or not, but we can't control that, so I don't think there is more to do? Or maybe putting the text in the `alt` attribute too? > [ðŸ”Ž] Does Joplin use ::before or ::after to include non-decorative content (see F87)? We use `::before` to render the checkboxes in the RTE checkbox lists. I suspect it would be difficult to improve this. > [ðŸ”Ž] Does Joplin use structural markup to achieve a visual-only effect? (F43 and related). **[Suggest close]** Very hard to say but generally we use semantic markup so I would think there are not many such instances. The link provides example of using `blockquote` for indentation or `h4` to make something bold and we generally don't do this. I think it's safe to tick that item off now. > [ðŸ”Ž] Meaningful sequences can be particularly easy to disrupt using flex-order or similar order-changing CSS. Are we using flex-order anywhere? See F1. **[Suggest close]** Same comment as above - as the HTML is relatively clean I suspect we don't have too many strange out of order sequences. We don't use `flex-order` as far as I can see. > [ðŸ”Ž] Does this include RTL support? (Related issue). **[Suggest close]** We do not officially support RTL for now. If certain things work it's great but I know there are still issues and fixing this would be a project of its own. > (Different task) Check the documentation website. **[Suggest close]** I've searched for basic colours in the documentation - green, blue, etc. and didn't find any instructions based on colours. Only possible exception is [here](https://joplinapp.org/help/api/tutorials/cm6_plugin/#style-the-active-line) where it says "The active line should now have a light-yellow background". But I'm not sure how that could be improved. Possibly also out of scope for this project (which is about accessibility for the end user rather than for developers). > [ðŸ”Ž] Does this require better by-default support for small screens? If so, a possible solution could be to minimize secondary panels (e.g. by moving them to an overflow tab) when low on space. **[Suggest close]** I'd think this is out of scope for the desktop app because we provide the mobile app for smaller devices > [ðŸ”Ž] Check color contrast between neighboring content. > [ðŸ”Ž] Check user interface components (non-text) in the desktop app for contrast in the default theme. > Add a high-contrast theme for the markdown editor? I think these three items are similar? Basically about having sufficient contrasts between adjacent elements. I couldn't actually find a tool to check this. The [WebAIM contrast checker](https://webaim.org/resources/contrastchecker/) is to compare foreground and background colour, which is not the same as comparing, for example, the colour the selected notebook background against the whole sidebar background colour. We need something to test adjacent colours it seems. We have a visible focus indicator in any case which would be part of the Sufficient Techniques: "G195: Using an author-supplied, visible focus indicator" > 1.4.12: Text spacing: [ðŸ”Ž] How can this be done with Joplin (if at all)? Is Joplin still usable in this case? I think that's for web pages where user can provide a user CSS stylesheet? As a test I think we should try to set a custom stylesheet for the Markdown editor, RTE and viewer with the mentioned properties and see if it still works. If it doesn't we should evaluate if there are simple fixes we can implement - if it's too complex we should drop it. And we shouldn't support this for the rest of the interface. The guideline mentions "content" which I think is understood to be articles, etc., not user interface elements. > [ðŸ”Ž] Currently, it's difficult to move the keyboard focus to the "new note"/"new to-do"/"sync" buttons **[Suggest close]** Not sure if something has changed but I was able to move the focus to all these buttons with both TAB and Shift+TAB > [ðŸ”Ž] Is it possible to cause the UI to flash more than three times? (Check cases involving dark mode transitioning to light mode and switching notes with resources that need to load). **[Suggest close]** I tried and couldn't get anything to flash three times. Including loading HTML notes. So I'd say we can skip this one. > [ðŸ”·] [ðŸ”Ž] Check for other cases where the focus can be hidden by another item. (Trash notification?) **[Suggest close]** I'm not sure I understand this guideline. But using the keyboard I could give focus to the notification "Cancel" button as would be expected. That notification also doesn't hide enough of the content or for long enough to be a problem. > 2.4.13. Focus Appearance (Level AAA) > > 2.5.5. Target Size (Enhanced) (Level AAA) > > 2.5.6. Concurrent Input Mechanisms (Level AAA) Should we skip the AAA items? > [ðŸ”Ž] Check for focus causing changes in context. **[Suggest close]** Even without accessibility in mind that would be bad design probably, and I can't think of any such instance. > [ðŸ”Ž] The keyboard shortcuts screen shows an error message only when the user hovers over or clicks on the "warning" icon. Is this sufficient? I'm not sure why it was done this way, and I don't feel it's very good. We should change it to display the message below the keyboard shortcut, unless there's a good reason for the current UI.

title: Investigate why decryption is slower
author: laurent22

comments.author: laurent22
comments.body:
It seems to be slower when decrypting on mobile (tested on Android), maybe due to the recent change to AES-256.

Probably we need to test with resources for various sizes on the Android emulator, see how long it takes to decrypt. Changing the chunk size might help: 

https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/blob/16d8a78d8a614a07886a99f696a6efaa76435f01/packages/lib/services/e2ee/EncryptionService.ts#L58

Ref: https://discourse.joplinapp.org/t/decryption-is-so-slow-on-android-2-minutes-per-1mb-note-that-it-makes-e2ee-unusable/32072/1

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
Here's what I've found so far:
- [SJCL has a separate AES/CCM encryption/decryption implementation when given an `ArrayBuffer`](https://github.com/bitwiseshiftleft/sjcl/blob/85caa53c281eeeb502310013312c775d35fe0867/core/convenience.js#L137) that [should be faster](https://github.com/bitwiseshiftleft/sjcl/pull/210). It's possible we're already using this, however â€” `sjcl.decrypt` accepts a JSON string for cyphertext and `sjcl` may be internally creating an ArrayBuffer. 
- If we want to switch to a native implementation, iOS' built-in [CryptoKit](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/cryptokit/aes/gcm) (the iOS native implementation) seems to only support AES GCM (not CCM). (I'm unsure whether `javax.crypto` in Android supports AES CCM). As such, it may make sense to eventually switch to AES GCM from AES CCM.

comments.author: wh201906
comments.body:
> * If we want to switch to a native implementation...

How about libsodium?

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
> How about libsodium?

I think `libsodium` would also require a switch to AES GCM: https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium/issues/739

comments.author: wh201906
comments.body:
> * `sjcl.decrypt` accepts a JSON string for cyphertext and `sjcl` may be internally creating an ArrayBuffer.

I skimmed the code and it looks like the files are encoded as base64 string first, then encrypted. I guess the conversion to base64 might slow down the process, and take extra storage.

comments.author: laurent22
comments.body:
Switching to a different lib would be for a future version since it's likely to be a lot of work.

For 2.12 either we find a way to make it fast again using sjcl, or we go back to AES-128. The current implementation may be more secure but unfortunately it's not usable.

Does changing the chunk size help?

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
laurent22
comments.body: Thanks for these detailed tests but somehow 1.2x difference is not what some users (including myself) are observing. It's more like 5 or 10 times slower (or more) at least with certain resources. I'll see if I can replicate this slow down, so that it can be compared with the previous decryption method

comments.author: laurent22
comments.body:
Thanks, so I guess the situation is that it will get faster as we increase the chunk size, until we fill up the RAM, at which point it will start swapping and becomes extremely slow. And I guess with AES-256 it tends to reach more quickly that limit.

I've just tried it and unfortunately I can't seem to replicate the same slow down I have on device. I think we're going to go back to AES-128 for 2.12 until we better understand the issue and how to tweak the encryption for performance.

> until we fill up the RAM, at which point it will start swapping and becomes extremely slow.

Android doesn't use swap (except for something like zram or zswap on some devices), so if the RAM gets filled, the app will likely be just killed by the OS.

This problem doesn't always occur, it just happens occasionally. I asked gemni AI getting the answer below:
The error you're seeing in Joplin on Windows 11, which includes the code snippet:

CSS

Note viewer body { overflow: hidden; }
#joplin-container-content {
    position: relative;
    overflow-y: auto;
    padding-left: 10px;

}
is not actually an error message in the traditional sense. It's the CSS code that Joplin uses to style the note viewer. This code is being displayed directly in your notes, which is the problem.

Here's a breakdown of why this happens and how to fix it:

Reason:

This issue usually arises due to a conflict or bug related to how Joplin renders or parses certain Markdown content, particularly when it involves HTML or CSS. It's been reported in the Joplin community before (as seen in the search results). The core issue is that this styling code, intended for the note viewer itself, is somehow being injected into the note content as plain text.

Solutions:

Update Joplin: The most straightforward solution is to ensure you're running the latest version of Joplin. Bugs are often fixed in newer releases. Check for updates within the Joplin application or download the latest version from the official Joplin website.

Check for Conflicting Plugins or Custom CSS: If you're using any Joplin plugins or have applied custom CSS through userchrome.css or userstyle.css, these could be interfering with the rendering process. Try temporarily disabling plugins or removing custom CSS to see if the issue resolves. If it does, re-enable them one by one to identify the culprit.

Inspect the Note Content: Carefully examine the Markdown content of the affected notes. Look for any unusual HTML tags, inline styles, or CSS code blocks that might be causing the problem. Sometimes, even seemingly innocuous HTML can trigger rendering issues. If you find any, try removing or correcting them.

Recreate the Note (if possible): If the issue is isolated to a few notes, try copying the content of the affected notes and creating new notes with that content. This can sometimes resolve underlying formatting issues.

User CSS workarounds (Advanced): If the problem persists and you're comfortable with CSS, you can try adding some CSS to your userstyle.css to hide the unwanted code. However, this is more of a workaround than a true fix. You could try something like this:

CSS

div.codeblock { /* Or a more specific selector if needed */
    display: none;
}
This would hide any <div> elements with the class "codeblock." You'll need to inspect the HTML source of the rendered note (using your browser's developer tools if needed) to find the appropriate CSS selector to target the unwanted code.

Important Note: The issue you're encountering is likely a bug or a rendering quirk within Joplin. The provided solutions are aimed at mitigating the problem. If the issue persists after trying these steps, it's recommended to report the bug on the Joplin GitHub repository or the Joplin forum, providing as much detail as possible (including the Joplin version, operating system, and steps to reproduce the issue). This will help the Joplin developers to identify and fix the root cause.

comments.author: mrjo118

@balnaimi I suspect the issue in this thread is the same as https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/12089 which someone else who is a Joplin server user has raised.

It's helpful to see that the activity in the logs for both issues appears to be the same.

I can't say the cause of these issues, however one thing I do know from running my own tests with syncing in Joplin is that if the server object which defines the notebook for a collection of notes is deleted, all the notes within that notebook can disappear from the Joplin UI despite the objects still existing on the server. So I suspect this is what has happened, as the logs all say 'non-note conflict' rather than note deletions. If you were not using Joplin server / cloud you could identify the relevant objects from the recycle bin on the server and restore them, and then create a new profile and re-sync with the sync target, which should allow the notes to be restored. But unfortunately with Joplin server / cloud there is no recycle bin and you can't manipulate the server objects directly.

Unfortunately I can't advise on how you could avoid this happening in future, but I can advise that until this bug has been fixed, in future you might want to make a full jex export before attempting any rename or re-organisation of notebooks, so you don't lose anything important if it happens again. If you're just moving notes between notebooks but without changing notebook names or structure, then I think you'll be alright.

I do have some questions though:
1. Is the notebook which disappeared one which was being shared?
2. If so, is it possible that any of the other users who the notebook was shared with renamed or restructured the folder at the same time that you did?
3. Has the notebook in question disappeared for other users which it is shared with?

Right, then how about doing nothing in this case? I think that could cause clients to be out of sync, but that can be resolved by the user, for example by updating the notebook title on other devices.

I see what you mean about bumping the updated_time property but it doesn't look like the sync system is designed to handle an item being modified during sync, and I seem to remember I was trying to avoid this as it probably causes all kind of strange issues.

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
> Right, then how about doing nothing in this case? I think that could cause clients to be out of sync, but that can be resolved by the user, for example by updating the notebook title on other devices.
> 
> I see what you mean about bumping the updated_time property but it doesn't look like the sync system is designed to handle an item being modified during sync, and I seem to remember I was trying to avoid this as it probably causes all kind of strange issues.

I think if you do nothing in this scenario, then it is going to mark it as a conflict every time you sync forevermore, regardless of which client you use. Because to reach this scenario, somehow the remote item was deleted without the user deleting the notebook locally, so most likely the matching local item exists and is marked as synced on every client. While the user wouldn't see any difference (the conflict would appear in the logs though), it would probably block any further updates to that object on the server without any prompt or warning to the user.

So I think you have to do something to break the cycle: either delete the local item or mark it back as unsynced so that it will be recreated on the next trigger of the sync (the latter being my suggestion - clear sync_time rather than update updated_time)

But we should probably go back to the original issue - the user was moving folders around and something got marked as deleted - why was that? I remember for shared notebook there's something where moving a notebook outside the shared notebook is considered a deletion, however if it's within the shared notebook it should not be a deletion. comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
I have done some investigation and found that the first time the evernote imported note is opened, the onFieldChange handler (NoteEditor.tsx) is triggered with a change to the 'body' field. I compared the contents of the note in the sqlite db before and after opening the imported note for the first time, and I found that while the text contents look the same, the binary representation of the note contents have different values:

before:
2d2d2d74747474742d2d2d0a2d2d2d74
747474742d2d2d0d3132333132333a0d
312e746573740d322e722e702e

after:
2d2d2d74747474742d2d2d0a2d2d2d74
747474742d2d2d0a3132333132333a0a
312e746573740a322e722e702e

The differences are instances of 0d (carriage return) are replaced with 0a (line feed) hex values after opening.
So the problem is that when you open an imported note for the first time, if it contains carriage returns they are immediately replaced with line feeds, which then triggers a save.

UPDATE: If others have not been able to reproduce it with the provided jex file, it may be an OS specific issue, or possibly even Windows 10 specific.

Also I only can reproduce the issue if the markdown editor is enabled before switching to the note for the first time. If I have the rich text editor enabled the first time, the updated time remains as it should be. If I then enable the markdown editor, if I switch to another note and then switch back to the note, the updated time gets updated. So it's possibly an upstream CodeMirror issue.

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
I think this is the cause:
https://github.com/codemirror/codemirror5/issues/3395

The problem is if the note being imported has a mixture of line break characters in a single document, which is the case here (some use carriage return, some use new line in the original note text), then CodeMirror will change the contents to use the same character sequence for all new lines. So it's likely something that would happen if you edit the same note on different operating systems.

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body: This issue may be a duplicate of #11382. #11382 seems to be caused by an issue with how Joplin saves the Rich Text Editor's content as Markdown. In particular, bulleted list items that contain a single user-resized image are saved incorrectly. When the Rich Text Editor loads from the saved Markdown, sub-list items immediately after the image are interpreted as HTML (and not as Markdown). Also see [this comment](https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/11382#issuecomment-2549477669). Note that list items after the first might still be list items (and perhaps interpreted as code?) in some cases. For example, starting with the following Markdown, ```markdown - - Sub-list item 1 - Sub-list item 2 ``` When resaved by the Rich Text Editor, the Markdown might lose the closing `` tag and become this: ```markdown - - Sub-list item 1 - Sub-list item 2 ``` Then, when loaded by the Rich Text Editor, "- Sub-list item 1" is interpreted as HTML. "- Sub-list item 2" is separated from item 1 by a blank line, so is still interpreted as Markdown: ![sub-list item just after an image has a dash for a bullet point and different indentation from the second list item](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9b237dc5-89eb-4238-bb40-abf81add2091)

comments.author: wind0204
comments.body:
in ~/.config/mimeapps.list:
```
[Default Applications]
text/markdown=vim.desktop
```

in ~/.config/joplin-desktop/settings.jsosn:
```
"editor": "xdg-open",
```
when `editor` is ""/null: joplin is frozen until the external editor is closed, and joplin-desktop doesn't even watch the file for the first note. unlike when `editor` is "xdg-open"

comments.author: wind0204
comments.body:
I've figured out the source of the problem. --I still don't understand why the first note to edit with vim is immune though

It turns out the default behavior of vi-incompatible vim when it writes to a file is, if it can move/rename the file without losing file attributes and/or link states it moves/renames the file to make a backup in case of IO error; And that causes unlink event on chokidar's file watch.

The current workaround I utilize is adding these lines after `set nocompatible` in `vimrc`
```
" To adapt to Joplin/chokidar's simple logic of file watching, Just take some extra time
" copying the original file when making a backup instead of quickly moving it.
" BTW, chokidar does actually take a measure when `atomic` option is not set to false
autocmd BufRead $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/joplin-desktop/* setlocal backupcopy=yes
```

I hope Joplin soon will come with a more sophisticated logic to adapt to the default backup behavior of vim.
vim is just doing its best for data safety, performance and possibly SSDs' lifetime, Please understand the complex behavior, @laurent22

comments.author: wind0204
comments.body:
It's weird that chokidar does take a measure to prevent this kind of problem and it should be on by default.

"`atomic` (default: true if `useFsEvents` and `usePolling` are false).
Automatically filters out artifacts that occur when using editors that use "atomic writes" instead of writing directly to the source file. If a file is re-added within 100 ms of being deleted, Chokidar emits a change event rather than unlink then add. If the default of 100 ms does not work well for you, you can override it by setting `atomic` to a custom value, in milliseconds."

title: Cursor blink rate ignores system settings on MacOS
author: timmb

comments.author: timmb
comments.body:
MacOS provides two global preferences to control the blink rate of the cursor when editing text:

- NSTextInsertionPointBlinkPeriodOn
- NSTextInsertionPointBlinkPeriodOff

It's particularly important for people like me who find it nearly impossible to focus while there is animation on the screen. On my system I have the On period set to 999999ms and the Off set to 0ms.


## Environment

Joplin version: 1.0.175
Platform: macOS 10.14.6 
OS specifcs: macOS
<!--
  Platform can be one of: macOS, Linux, Windows, Android, iOS, terminal (or a combination)
  OS specifcs: e.g. OS version, Linux distribution, Android/iOS version, ...
-->

## Steps To Reproduce

1. Open Terminal
2. Enter these two commands

This is just the way that 2 way sync works. With updates to files, you can use timestamp to determine if a file has changed. But with deletions, you cannot compare timestamps because a deletion on the server means there is nothing remaining to compare to. comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
"It's an anomaly caused by a human intentionally, it is not even a sync yet."
Based on the reproduction steps you have specified, you have specified that you have synced both before and after creating the snapshot (and new note), so the algorithm is working as designed.

"but this is a typical human-interval-needed-conflict"
No it's not. A webdav server has no concept of whether an item is synced, only the client does. So requiring human intevention in this scenario would mean that every time a genuine deletion is made by a user on one client, all other clients would require human intervention to determine whether the local deletion should occur when the client is synced. This would not be very practical from a usability perspective.

If the note count is completely different on your Android compared to your Linux device when they are both synced up to date, then that is a completely different issue.

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
On a side note, for what reason do you want to restore a snapshot of your WebDAV server?

Because of the way the 2 way sync works, you should only restore a snapshot for emergency data recovery, if you have suffered data loss in your Joplin clients and need to get data back, with the compromise that you may lose data created after the snapshot was created. This is generally the compromise of restoring any kind of backup though.

Normally, the data on the server should not be changed outside of the Joplin client, because it is the source of truth for all clients and messing something up can then mess up all of your clients.

comments.author: gineer01
comments.body:
`joplin search --index` command would be very useful. 

In addition, should sync and API calls trigger indexing automatically? For example, API calls that update data (e.g., POST, PUT) should trigger indexing so that the next API call to `/search` API will reflect the new data instead of waiting for indexing by a separate `joplin search --index` or TUI. Similarly, after a `joplin sync`, Joplin should know any note has changed by the sync and can add indexing at the end? 

In these cases, API and sync code have more information what has changed and can be more efficient. If we expect users to call `joplin search --index`, I think many will just call that command "just to be sure" to avoid stale results. This is less efficient because if no data has changed, calling `joplin search --index` is just a waste?

comments.author: laurent22
comments.body: Or maybe we don't need `joplin search --index` - instead just change the existing `joplin search` and call indexing every time it starts

comments.author: gineer01
comments.body:
What does `joplin search` do? I don't see it in https://joplinapp.org/help/apps/terminal/#commands . 

I use `joplin server` to start the API and use search API to get result. Calling indexing every time `joplin server` starts is not enough. API calls (POST/PUT/DELETE calls) can update notes after `joplin server` starts. I think we need the proposed `joplin search --index` to index new/updated/deleted notes again. Ideally, if API calls indexing after each update (POST/PUT/DELETE calls), it's more efficient. Don't need to index for read-only operations like `GET /notes` or `GET /search`.

author: personalizedrefrigerator

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
### Operating system

Linux

### Joplin version

86c035c90973e7b9824d7fefb3134bcaa94ad563

### Desktop version info

N/A

### Current behaviour

Updating the mobile note editor, then quickly unmounting the component results in loss of the last-entered data.

In particular,
- In a testing environment, waiting > 100ms since the last edit seems to consistently allow the last changes to be saved.
- If the component is unmounted < 100ms (e.g. 98ms) since the last edit, the last changes are lost.

**On a real device, this 100ms threshold may be greater.**

Test case: [commit](https://github.com/personalizedrefrigerator/joplin/commit/86c035c90973e7b9824d7fefb3134bcaa94ad563#diff-d223d870ea23c6f3006a45a8c57c0dc9cdb36fe52907f0e86dacbbfbe3445675R194).

### Expected behaviour

The last change to the editor should be preserved, even if made very briefly before closing the editor.

### Notes

- Similar to https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/11124, but probably a different issue (#11124 is specific to sync).

### Logs

_No response_

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body: Does unmounting the component happen just when exiting the app, or does it happen also when exiting edit mode to save the note?

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
I can see that if I add a log entry in the componentWillUnmount() function in app-mobile Note.tsx, that it gets called when exiting the note completely i.e. going back to the note list. It isn't getting called if I close the app via the Android recent list while the note is open.

Should the title of this issue therefore instead be: 'Last editor input is lost if changes are made less than about 100ms before closing the note' ?

Also, maybe the problem and solution outlined here could aid with a resolution for the issue? https://medium.com/@minduladilthushan/resolving-the-state-not-updating-immediately-issue-in-react-js-febf5959c0cf

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
> Should the title of this issue therefore instead be: 'Last editor input is lost if changes are made less than about 100ms before closing the note' ?

Possibly, though it depends on the cause of the issue:
- `Note.tsx` uses an `AsyncActionQueue` to schedule note saves. If scheduled items in the queue aren't being processed when the app is closed from the recent app list, then the title should remain "before closing the app".
    - The relevant `AsyncActionQueue` is created here: https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/blob/0e1f6f48ef846f85430b29259dda8809218ef968/packages/app-mobile/components/screens/Note.tsx#L614
- The note editor runs in a `WebView`, which transfers its updated content to `Note.tsx` when changed. If this issue is caused when the last editor content fails to transfer to `Note.tsx`, then the issue title should be changed to end with "before closing the note".

comments.author: mrjo118
mrjo118
comments.body:
Apologies, I jumped the gun a bit. After adding some additional logging and changing the code a bit, I can confirm that a note change scheduled using debounce does indeed execute, even after componentWillUnmount and the save action queue has completed. So that is not the issue.
Looking at your old PR https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/10134 , if in some cases it takes several seconds to work through the backlog of the save action queue, then indeed the user may have exited the note and then exited the app as well within that time. As soon as the user exits the app, any background processing will stop, so any items left in the queue will be lost. I confirmed this by adding logging at the end of the componentWillUnmount method, setting a delay of 10 seconds and writing another log in the callback. If I exit the note so the first log entry is written, then exit the app using the back button before the 10 seconds is up, the second log entry never gets written. The componentWillUnmount method is asynchronous so the user will be back on the list view before the processing completes.

Would it be possible with a React Native app to make some sort of visual indicator on the note screen while the note is saving, which persists onto the note list after exiting the note, until the save is completed? Or another option and maybe simpler would be to make the back button on the note (when switching from edit to to view mode) wait at intervals until the save action queue is empty, before executing the code to switch it to view mode. That way it will block the UI until all changes are saved

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
I made some further tests, and it turns out there are 3 issues:
-**Last editor input is lost if the app is closed before all queued changes have been saved** - In manual testing of queued changes, I found that the 100 ms buffer between registering save actions greatly reduces the backlog and time required to execute it. As the the time to execute is unlikely to become significantly long, and large notes take a bit of time to render the note after exiting edit mode anyway, this is probably not that likely to occur providing that the user always exits the note before closing the app
-**Last editor input is lost if the user exits a note within 100 ms after making changes, where consecutive changes were made** - I have attached a video below demonstrating this using the prebuilt Joplin 3.1.5 apk on Android emulator. The user would have to be super quick to make a change and exit both edit and view mode of the note for this occur, so again it's unlikely to happen. It's probably related to the fact that the note was unmounted before the change could be even finish rendering in view mode, so the state might not yet have been updated
-**Last editor input is sometimes lost when exiting the note editor after making changes** - I have been able to fairly consistently reproduce this using the prebuilt Joplin 3.1.5 apk on Android emulator using a very large note by making text changes following pasting a chunk of text. I found that there is a specific error which appears in the logs during the period which I edit the note (which looks to align roughly with when I pasted the text) when the issue is reproduced. I've raised a new bug report with my findings for it https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/11317. This could possibly be the cause of the intermittent lost input issues which Joplin has had for a long time
EDIT: This issue is now fixed in the 3.2.x releases

comments.body: Hi, I looked on the Kanban board but didn't see this issue so I hope to pick it up. I am still investigating but think it results from processing the file_paths in **importLocalFiles** in _packages/lib/services/interop/InteropService_Importer_Md.ts_.

comments.author: tue-AqielOostenbrug
comments.body:
The problem with the `./file1` appears to result from bad parsing by the filename(...) function in packages/utils/path.ts:
`filename(${dirname(filePath)}/${trimmedLink}), true);` returns `${dirname(filePath)}` whilst `${dirname(filePath)}/file1` is expected.

Additionally, the problem with `file2` appears to result from the formulation of the variable `pathWithExtension` in the importLocalFiles(...) in packages/lib/services/interop/InteropService_Importer_Md.ts: `const pathWithExtension = ${attachmentPath}.${fileExtension(trimmedLink)};` yields `pathWithExtension = ${dirname(filePath)}/file1.` whilst `pathWithExtension = ${dirname(filePath)}/file1` is expected.

I believe that this issue might relate to the cause of people losing their notes when using OneDrive as the sync target. In this thread https://discourse.joplinapp.org/t/restore-deleted-backups/43230 it was found that multiple instances of the Graph folder can be created on OneDrive without the user initiating a new login, and when that happens it could either segment the notes across 2 profiles or leave all the notes behind on the old profile.

This recent comment on the upstream issue also suggests that if the user currently has a Joplin folder on OneDrive, it may be spontaneously moved or de-referenced, to use a Graph folder instead https://github.com/OneDrive/onedrive-api-docs/issues/1866#issuecomment-2577752192

comments.author: mrjo118
comments.body:
I have a proposal for how the failsafe could be hardened to be more protective from data loss on all sync targets, and optionally a possible way to allow the user to recover from the OneDrive 'special' folder suddenly changing when the authentication is refreshed:

During the delta step of the synchronization code, make it check whether the sync target (remote) contains an info.json file, following each invocation of the delta api which fetches the list of remote items, and also when synchronization is started (just before info.json is created). If it does not, then trigger a failsafe error specifying that the sync target is empty or damaged. To avoid hitting this error when doing the initial sync on a device, bypass this error if the local database contains no items in the sync_items table matching the current sync target (then when it starts syncing it will create the info.json so that subsequent syncs should work without issue).

If the sync target is OneDrive, also destroy the existing authentication when hitting that specific failsafe error, to force the user to log into OneDrive again when they next press the sync button, in a hope that it will re-authenticate with the original 'special' folder.

> 1- On the Joplin server web interface (reported version on the interface: "Joplin Server v2.12.1, copyright Â© 2021-2024 JOPLIN.") , create two new accounts: *testmaster1* and *testuser1*.
> 2- On Windows PC (Joplin 3.0.15), create a new profile and sync it to *testmaster1*.
> 3- On a Mac (Joplin 3.0.15), create a new profile and sync it to *testuser 1*.
> 4- On the Windows PC (*testmaster1* account), create a test notebook with a test note inside. Share the notebook with *testuser1*, sync.
> 5- On the Mac (*testuser1* account), sync will bring up the sharing dialog - Accept the sharing. The test notebook will appear with the test note inside.
> 6- Modification to this existing note will be synced bidirectionally (both *testmaster1*>*testuser1* and *testuser1*>*testmaster1*). **This is normal behavior**
> 7- Now create a new note either on *testmaster1*'s or *testuser1*'s side inside the shared notebook and sync it up to the server.
> 8- This note will not sync to the other user. **This is the bug**
> 9- Additional test: if you stop the notebook sharing from *testmaster1*, sync *testmaster1*, sync *testuser1* to clear the shared notebook, then re-invite *testuser1* and resync *testuser1*, the new note created at step 8 will appear on *testuser1*'s side.
> 10- Additional test: if you sync two different machines on *testmaster1*, the created note will sync on both machines.
> 
> So the bug is precisely the **syncing of note creation between users of shared notebooks**, both in the master>user and user>master directions (master being the account that shares the notebook). I suspect this won't work in a user1>user2 situation too.

Ref: https://discourse.joplinapp.org/t/sync-problem-with-joplin-server-new-notes-dont-sync-but-delete-modify-are-ok/41266/3?u=laurent

title: Joplin and Extremely High Memory Usage
author: Maghsad

comments.author: Maghsad
comments.body: ### Operating system **macOS** Version: 15.5 (24F74) ### Joplin version 3.3.12 ### Desktop version info Joplin 3.3.12 (prod, darwin) ### Current behaviour First, I would like to thank you for your continued efforts in developing and maintaining such a valuable open-source note-taking application. Hope my constructive feedback helps to improve Joplin by addressing such a serious concern: When completely **inactive** (no user interaction, no open notes, and running in the background), Joplin 3.3.12 (prod, darwin) on macOS 15.5 consumes about 1.5 GB of memory, as observed in the macOS Activity Monitor. This includes: - A â€œJoplin Helper (Renderer)â€ process using over 300 MB - A GPU helper process consuming over 100 MB - Multiple other Renderer processes, each using about 75 MB Even modern resource-intensive applications such as Chrome or Firefox with many open tabs and many plug-ins manage their idle memory footprint significantly better. This is not only unexpected but also unacceptable for a note-taking application, especially when no activity is taking place. ### Expected behaviour When idle, Joplin should consume minimal memory, similar to other productivity tools. Background processes should be optimized, and memory use should reflect the app's current workload, which, in this case, is none. It is worth emphasizing that such RAM usage is extremely high even for many open documents for an app like Joplin. A thorough resolution to manage such resource intensiveness is crucial. This appears to be a serious performance issue and possibly a memory leak or architectural inefficiency. Please consider prioritizing a fix in an upcoming release. Thank you again for the hard work your team continues to put into Joplin. Itâ€™s an app with significant potential, and I hope to see this memory issue addressed soon. ### Logs _No response_

comments.body:
Thank you for reporting this!

For comparison,  "Clear cache and re-download language data files" seems to work for me (on Fedora 42 Linux, with Joplin 3.3.12 (dev)):
- Shows a confirmation dialog.
- After pressing OK, restarts Joplin.
- Logs the following:
    ```
    OcrDriverTesseract: Clearing cached language data...
    OcrDriverTesseract: Clearing language data with key ./eng.traineddata
    ```
- At this point, inspecting the `keyval-store` indexedDB table (using the "Application" tab in the development tools) reveals that the `./eng.traineddata` cached model is no longer downloaded.

Follow-up questions:
- After clicking "Clear cache and re-download language data files", is "OcrDriverTesseract: Clearing language data with key ./eng.traineddata" added to Joplin's log file?
    - Logs can either be accessed from Joplin's development tools (Help > Toggle developer tools, includes recent logs) or from the `log.txt` file in the profile directory (Help > Open profile directory, includes older logs).
    - If there is an error, it should log "OCR: Failed to clear language data cache." followed by the error message.
- Are new images (not scanned previously) processed using the new OCR models?

4. NVDA will reporting:
      - "Trash Expanded, press space to collapse. expanded"
      - "No notes in here. Create one by clicking on "New note"."

### Expected behaviour

In a series of tips in step (4) I think there is some redundancy:

e.g.

> "No notes in here. Create one by clicking on "New note"."
> "This subfolder of the trash has no notes. "

comments.author: cary-rowen
comments.body: I'm really happy to see a series of recent efforts by Joplin on A11y, which is very useful for screen reader users.

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
Thank you for the feedback!

> "Trash Expanded, press space to collapse. expanded"

I'm linking to the relevant code:
https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/blob/06359834d680472b9f02e79995b3f2989c21e425/packages/app-desktop/gui/Sidebar/listItemComponents/ExpandIcon.tsx#L26

This label was present originally because the "expand"/"collapse" icons were individually focusable buttons (older versions of Joplin did not properly use the treeview pattern). Whether a folder is expanded/collapsed is now communicated through `aria-` properties. As such, this label should no longer be necessary.

> "No notes in here. Create one by clicking on "New note"."
> "This subfolder of the trash has no notes. "

This may be related to [giving the "No notes in here. ..." message the `status` role](https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/commit/157ad2c0cd16a586312b8140e66592b3b270577a#diff-d082040fd7ff053ca6bdb99d0b847aaadba5fa17a48138a8cc2cdd53d66a67daR206). This is done to notify the user when there are no results (when using the standard search). Here are some options:
- Only give the "No notes in here. ..." message the `status` role if currently searching.
- Include the number of search results in a separate `status` live region.
- Follow the [Combobox Pattern](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/combobox/) for search and search results (similar to the Goto Anything dialog).

title: Add a text layer over OCR-ed PDF files
author: laurent22

comments.author: laurent22
comments.body:
When we OCR a PDF file we essentially make a screenshot of each page and process it. During the OCR process, Tesseract also provides coordinates to tell us where in the image the text should be, and we already save this information in the `ocr_details` column.

Using this information, we should recreate the PDF, and overlay the text on top of it. The PDF appearance needs to be identical to the original document, so it will be basically a file made of multiple screenshots. On top there should be an overlay, probably an invisible one. And it should be possible to select and copy and paste the text.

The aim is to make PDF files processed by Joplin more accessible. Some users have to deal with PDF documents that are essentially images which can't be read by screen reader tools. So by adding the actual text to it it should work.

For now, we can expose the feature with a right-click on the document with a menu item next to "View OCR text", for example "Create accessible document". It would take the PDF file, combine it with `ocr_details`, and output a new document.

Example of document: [Arrete22pages.pdf](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/20624513/Arrete22pages.pdf)

title: Mobile: Accessibility: Comply with WCAG 2.2
author: personalizedrefrigerator

comments.author: personalizedrefrigerator
comments.body:
# Summary

See https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/10795 for more information about this task.


**Status**:
| Task | Done | Total | Percent done |
|------|------|-------|--------------|
| Items marked with "[â—]" (Usually Level A items)  | 37 | 65 | 56.9% |
| Items marked with "[ðŸŸ¡]" (Usually Level AA items) | 6  | 23 | 26% |
| Needs research    | 1  | 22 | 4.5% |


# Notes

**Some accessibility work and issues from before starting this project**: https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/10122, https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/10253, https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/8715

**General notes**:

- This section focuses on Joplin for Android.
- See [this note](https://www.w3.org/TR/wcag2ict-22/#content-on-and-off-the-web) for information about applying the WCAG to non-web content.
- [`react-native-ama`'s documentation](https://commerce.nearform.com/open-source/react-native-ama/checklist/) includes accessibility checklists specific to React Native that might be helpful.
- While React Native allows exposing the language of the app [to accessibility tools on iOS](https://reactnative.dev/docs/0.74/view#accessibilitylanguage-ios), this may not currently be possible on Android without custom native code.
- Uncategorized/external keyboard: `TextInput` blocks focus (https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/45801)
    - May be fixed in React Native >= 0.79.
- \[ðŸ”Ž\] Evaluate the mobile application and create a task list based on the WCAG 2.2 spec.

**Uncategorized issues**:
- [ ] **Screen reader**: When closing the voice typing dialog, focus jumps to the "back" button at the top of the screen.
- [ ] **Screen reader**: It seems difficult to act on selected items (e.g. select items, then duplicate) with a screen reader.
     - Proposed fix: Add accessibility actions (using a React Native API) to items in the note list.
- [ ] **Screen reader**: It seems difficult to navigate to/from the Markdown toolbar using a screen reader.
- [ ] **Screen reader**: After activating items on the Markdown toolbar, there's no feedback to indicate that an action was completed. (E.g. after clicking "Header 5", it seems unclear whether a header was added/removed and where).
     - A [pull request](https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11441) for this was closed (in part due to the complexity of how it got localization to work in the editor). Feedback on whether this should be implemented would be welcome!
- [ ] **Screen reader**: Missing regions.
    - **To-do**: Check whether it's possible to add `navigation`/`main`/... regions with React Native — the [supported accessibility `role`s](https://reactnative.dev/docs/accessibility#role) seem much more limited than what's available on web. This might be possible with an external dependency.

> [!NOTE]
>
> For now, most of this evaluation focuses on mobile/Android. For keyboard accessibility (unless TalkBack is enabled), [React Native has focus issues](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/45801) with its built-in `TextInput` component.

# Checklist


## 1.1. Text alternatives

### 1.1.1. [Non-text Content](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#non-text-content) (A)

> All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below.
> - **Controls, Input**: If non-text content is a control or accepts user input, then it has a [name](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#dfn-name) that describes its purpose. (Refer to Success Criterion 4.1.2 for additional requirements for controls and content that accepts user input.)
>  \[ ...other exceptions... \]
> - **Decoration, Formatting, Invisible**: If non-text content is pure decoration, is used only for visual formatting, or is not presented to users, then it is implemented in a way that it can be ignored by assistive technology.

- [x] [â—] Sidebar dismiss button -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11056
- [x] [â—] Settings: Switch, textboxes missing labels -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11358
- [x] [â—] Attach file/sort by dialogs backdrop dismiss button -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11957
	- Related, but not resolved by: https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11395
- [x] [â—] Currently, the backdrop (which can be tapped to dismiss dialogs) isn't accessibility focusable and doesn't have a label for most dialogs  -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11957
	- In some cases, a separate close button is present in the UI (which does the same thing as tapping on the backdrop).
- [x] [â—] Slider missing description -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11822
	- It doesn't seem to be possible to add a programmatic label to `@react-native-community/slider` (based on the [list of props in its README](https://github.com/callstack/react-native-slider) & an attempt to set `accessibilityHint`/`accessibilityLabeledBy`).
- [x] [â—] Close button for note actions menu missing label -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11954
	- Fixing this may require patching/submitting a pull request to `react-native-popup-menu` ([related issue](https://github.com/instea/react-native-popup-menu/issues/138)).
- [x] [â—] Label the "add profile" button -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11797

### 1.2.1 - 1.2.3. Audio and Video (A)

- [ ] [ðŸ”·] Prerecorded audio and video would be user-created (attached as files in notes). While users are currently able to provide their own audio/video transcripts, it may make sense to include an "accessibility check" button that checks for unlabelled audo/video/images. (I think OneNote has this).


**Note**:  Â§1.2.4-1.2.9 are all related to audio/video recordings/streams, which is not included in Joplin mobile by default.


### 1.3.1. [Info and Relationships](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#info-and-relationships) (A)

The text description should be near the information it is describing (when the page is linearized), such as in the parent element or in the adjacent element.

### 1.3.2. [Meaningful sequence](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#meaningful-sequence) (A)

	- This might not be necessary â€” what counts as "determined by the user agent" in this case? See [discussion](https://github.com/w3c/wcag/issues/522#issuecomment-2009842227).
	- The "understanding" page does include "This criterion does not apply to scrolling enabled by the user-agent."
- [ ] [ðŸŸ¡] (ðŸ–‹ï¸) **Drawing**: Add a way to create shapes with only a single pointer.
	- Check how other apps do this. One option might be to make a "click" gesture add shapes when using a shape tool. However, it might be difficult to determine whether a user intends to click or draw.

### 2.5.8. [Target size](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#target-size-minimum) (minimum)
> The size of the target for pointer inputs is at least 24 by 24 CSS pixels, except where:
> 
> - **Spacing:** Undersized targets (those less than 24 by 24 CSS pixels) are positioned so that if a 24 CSS pixel diameter circle is centered on the bounding box of each, the circles do not intersect another target or the circle for another undersized target;
> - **Equivalent:** The function can be achieved through a different control on the same page that meets this criterion;
> - **Inline:** The target is in a sentence or its size is otherwise constrained by the line-height of non-target text;
> - **User agent control:** The size of the target is determined by the user agent and is not modified by the author;
> - **Essential:** A particular presentation of the target is essential or is legally required for the information being conveyed.

- The accessibility scanner marks a few touch targets (that seem to be actual touch targets) as smaller than 48x48 px, but these are all above 24x24 px.

## 3.1. Readable
### 3.1.1. [Language of Page](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#language-of-page) (A)
> The default human language of each web page can be programmatically determined.

- [ ] [â—] This currently isn't met. See what can be done here.
	- **Related**: [Discussion in the w3c/matf GitHub repo](https://github.com/w3c/matf/issues/14).
	- Based on the above, there seem to be APIs for iOS [and Android](https://github.com/w3c/matf/issues/14#issuecomment-2536793357) for declaring the app locale.

### 3.1.2. [Language of parts](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#language-of-parts) (AA)
> The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding text.

- [ ] [ðŸŸ¡] [ðŸ”Ž] Is it possible to apply this to fallback text for partial app localisations?
	- For example, if a string isn't translated by the community, it's currently loaded as English text.

### 3.1.3 - 3.1.6 (AAA)

Skipped.

## 3.2. Predictable
### 3.2.1. [On focus](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#on-focus) (A)

> When any user interface component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context. 

> [!NOTE]
>
> The WCAG defines "changes of context" to be:
> > major changes that, if made without user awareness, can disorient users who are not able to view the entire page simultaneously
> 
> It includes "focus" and "content that changes the meaning of the web page" as examples.

Screen reader/keyboard focus does not seem to cause changes in context in the mobile app.


### 3.2.2. [On Input](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#on-input) (A)
> Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component.

- [ ] [â—] [ðŸ”Ž] To check: Does toggling a task in the note list cause a change in context (e.g. focus change) when the list re-sorts?
    - Not for short lists, but maybe for long lists.

### 3.2.3. [Consistent Navigation](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#consistent-navigation) (AA)
> Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple web pages within a set of web pages occur in the same relative order each time they are repeated, unless a change is initiated by the user. 

Joplin uses the same header component for different screens and does not seem to re-order the header buttons on different screens. As such, this should be met.


### 3.2.3. [Consistent Identification](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/consistent-identification.html) (AA)
> Components that have the same functionality within a set of web pages are identified consistently. 

- [ ] [ðŸŸ¡] [ðŸ”Ž] Check: Do the checkboxes in the note list have similar labels to those shown when viewing a note?
- [ ] [ðŸŸ¡] [ðŸ”Ž] Check: Are the items in the note actions menu assigned labels consistent with those in the Markdown toolbar?



### 3.2.5. Change on request (AAA)

Skipped (level AAA).

### 3.2.6. [Consistent help](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/consistent-help.html) (A)
> If a web page contains any of the following help mechanisms, and those mechanisms are repeated on multiple web pages within a set of web pages, they occur in the same order relative to other page content, unless a change is initiated by the user:
> 
> - Human contact details;
> - Human contact mechanism;
> - Self-help option;
> - A fully automated contact mechanism.

Current places with contact/help information:
- Settings:
	- This is a single screen, in which information should always be in the same place (perhaps unless showing as a search result in settings).
- Drawing:
	- Help buttons, if available, are always the button just after the "toggle menu" button.
- Plugins:
	- [ ] [ðŸ”Ž] Installed plugins and not-installed plugins have different ways of accessing the "about" page for the plugin in search results. Check whether the success criterion applies to this. If so, change the plugin search results such that they have a consistent layout. (I don't think it applies due to the "repeated on multiple web pages within a set of web pages" statement).

## 3.3. Input assistance

### 3.3.1. [Error identification](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#error-identification) (A)
> If an [input error](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#dfn-input-error) is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.

- [x] [â—] Encryption config screen: Password errors for secondary keys are indicated with an "âŒ" emoji. This might not count as text -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11874
	- Also check that "âŒ" is read by screen readers (without needing to increase verbosity settings).
- [ ]  [ðŸ”Ž] Check the sign-in screen for sync targets.

### 3.3.2. [Labels or instructions](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/labels-or-instructions.html) (A)
> Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.

This success criterion may be met. Cases that need to be looked into include:
- The checkbox next to a note title. This may be considered labelled by the note title.

> [!NOTE]
>
> This success criterion is different from SC 1.3.1. From the "understanding" document:
> > This success criterion does not require that labels or instructions be correctly marked up, identified, or associated with their respective controls - this aspect is covered separately by 1.3.1: Info and Relationships. It is possible for content to pass this success criterion (providing relevant labels and instructions) while failing Success Criterion 1.3.1 (if the labels or instructions aren't correctly marked up, identified, or associated).

### 3.3.3. [Error suggestion](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#error-suggestion) (AA)
> If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the content.

- Encryption config screen:
	- Enabling encryption with non-matching passwords: A "Passwords do not match" dialog box is shown when clicking "enable" if the passwords do not match. Similarly, the dialog box states "Password cannot be empty" if an empty password is provided.
- Number settings inputs â€” suggestions are shown below the input (e.g. "Keep note history for cannot be less than 1").
- Sync setup â€” "check synchronization configuration button" is available for certain sync targets.

### 3.3.4. [Error prevention](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#error-prevention-legal-financial-data) (AA)
> For web pages that cause legal commitments or financial transactions for the user to occur, that modify or delete user-controllable data in data storage systems, or that submit user test responses, at least one of the following is true:
> - **Reversible**: Submissions are reversible.
> - **Checked**: Data entered by the user is checked for input errors and the user is provided an opportunity to correct them.
> - **Confirmed**: A mechanism is available for reviewing, confirming, and correcting information before finalizing the submission.

Joplin can "delete user-controllable data in data storage systems" (e.g. delete notes). At present:
- Items are deleted to the trash folder.
- A confirmation dialog is shown when a user clicks "permanently delete" from the trash or long-presses on "Trash", then selects "empty trash".
- [ ] [ðŸ”Ž] Are Joplin's current checks related to data on the sync target sufficient?
	- Check the case where a user misconfigures the sync target (e.g. [the deletions here](https://discourse.joplinapp.org/t/all-files-deleted-on-android-application-deleteaction-sync-deletelocal/44829/3)).

### 3.3.5-3.3.6 (AAA)

SC 3.3.5-3.3.6 are level AAA and thus omitted from this document.

### 3.3.7. [Redundant entry](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#redundant-entry) (A)
<blockquote>

Information previously entered by or provided to the user that is required to be entered again in the same process is either:
- auto-populated, or
- available for the user to select.

Except when:

- re-entering the information is essential,
- the information is required to ensure the security of the content, or
- previously entered information is no longer valid.
</blockquote>

- [ ] [â—] Pre-populate search in the Markdown editor with the global search query.

### 3.3.8 [Accessible Authentication](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#accessible-authentication-minimum) (AA)
> A cognitive function test (such as remembering a password or solving a puzzle) is not required for any step in an authentication process unless that step provides at least one of the following:

- Joplin uses `TextInput`s for passwords, which support copy and paste. [Copy and paste should be sufficient for this](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/accessible-authentication-minimum.html#copy-paste).


## 4.1. Compatible

**Note**: [SC 4.1.1](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#parsing) is marked as (Obsolete and removed).

### 4.1.2. [Name, role, value](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/name-role-value.html) (A)
> For all user interface components (including but not limited to: form elements, links and components generated by scripts), the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set by the user can be programmatically set; and notification of changes to these items is available to user agents, including assistive technologies.

- [x] [â—] Notebook toggle state (whether a notebook is expanded or not) -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11556
- [x] [â—] Notebook depth in the sidebar -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11556
- [x] [â—] Notebook depth in the sidebar -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11556
- [x] [â—] Note selection state in the note list -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11424
- [x] [â—] Mark note properties buttons as buttons -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11432
- [x] Use `accessibilityRole="button"` on touchable button-like items
	- [x] [â—] Note list items -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11419
	- [x] [â—] Tag list items -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11420
	- [ ] [â—]  "Open section" buttons in settings.
	- [ ] [â—]  Items in the note actions menu. 
- [x] [â—] Use `accessibilityRole="togglebutton"` or `accessibilityRole="checkbox"` on checkbox-like items.
	- [x] Tag list items (for adding/removing tags) -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11421
- [x] [â—] Mark the selected profile as selected in the profiles screen -- https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/pull/11797
- [ ] [â—] Notebook depth in the notebook dropdown selector
- [ ] [â—] [ðŸ”Ž] Paragraphs in the Markdown editor? (See https://github.com/laurent22/joplin/issues/12031)
	- On Android, certain screen readers are unable to use paragraph navigation in the mobile Markdown editor, possibly because each line is a `div`. Check whether adding appropriate `role` information would help with this (or be confusing, since CodeMirror doesn't necessarily render all lines outside the viewport).

### 4.1.3. Status messages (AA)
> In content implemented using markup languages, status messages can be programmatically determined through role or properties such that they can be presented to the user by assistive technologies without receiving focus.

- [ ] [â—] [ðŸ”Ž] The statement specifies "content implemented using markup languages", so may not apply to Joplin mobile. If it does, check the following:
	- Sync error message.
	- Error messages for number inputs in settings.


# Notes on accessibility testing

## Screen reader testing

For items related to screen reader accessibility, I'm testing primarily with the following screen readers:

- Linux: [Orca](https://help.gnome.org/users/orca/stable/introduction.html.en)
- Windows: [NVDA](https://www.nvaccess.org/about-nvda/)
- MacOS: VoiceOver
- iOS: VoiceOver
    - Note: Enabling VoiceOver globally in MacOS also enables it for the iOS simulator
- Android: TalkBack
    - Note: If testing on an emulator, [the Android Accessibility Suite](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.marvin.talkback) may have to be installed from the Play Store.

## Mobile: Finding contrast issues

On Android, the [Accessibility Scanner](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/accessibility/testing#accessibility-scanner) may also be helpful in identifying and fixing certain accessibility issues (e.g. contrast, unlabeled content).

comments.body:
> Uncategorized/external keyboard: TextInput blocks focus (https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/45801)

Regarding this point, I gave it a go adding the https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-native-external-keyboard dependency and replacing the usage of the TextInput component to be a KeyboardExtendedInput component. Out of the box this change alone does fix the issue on Android (I have not tested on IOS) so that you can tab or use the arrow keys on an external keyboard to switch between all the settings options without getting blocked by the TextInput - I also tested it with Talkback and it correctly reads the value. Note that the styling of the TextInput does require a bit of tinkering though to match the existing styling for a TextInput, as by default the width of the input contracts to the size of the input value instead of being fixed. Also note that when the KeyboardExtendedInput is in focus via the tab or arrows keys, you have to press the space bar first, in order to allow changing the value. If you press the field with your finger or mouse click though, it will immediately be in edit mode and you can start typing the value.

Also there looks to be an additional accessibility issue when using an external keyboard. You can open up a dropdown field by pressing enter when it is in focus, however it is not possible to change the selected value in the dropdown using an external keyboard, as far as I can tell, as the dropdown items are no selectable with the arrow keys.
EDIT: Actually, this is not an issue. You can select a drop down item if you get the dropdown in focus, press enter, and then press tab, which then allows you to select an option using the arrow keys. Though sometimes you have to press tab twice in order to get the dropdown items to be in focus

FYI this is just for informational purposes. I don't think I will be investing further effort to implement these changes for a PR.

comments.body:
> Uncategorized/external keyboard: TextInput blocks focus (https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/45801)

It might be fixed upstream! From [an upstream commit message](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/commit/3420eb87b01f42092c1691a1f6544f20d244cc60):

> This is breaking keyboard navigation. Pressing tab or arrow keys will no-op if the next destination is a `TextInput`. This is because Android will call `requestFocus` from [here](https://cs.android.com/android/platform/superproject/main/+/main:frameworks/base/core/java/android/view/ViewRootImpl.java;l=7868?q=performFocusNavigation) when handling key events. Notably, Explore By Touch (TalkBack) swiping gestures WOULD focus `TextInputs` since they go through `ExploreByTouchHelper` methods which we override to call the proper `requestFocusInternal()` method.

Based on this, upgrading to React Native >= 0.79 may fix the issue.

_No response_

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/48cbb9cf-3959-465d-978e-8a1d70620743)

body {

comments.author: bwat47
comments.body:
> I'd say this is a feature because if the text is white you also want to copy and the paste dark background too. Otherwise most apps have an option to paste without formatting

The problem with paste without formatting is that you lose all of the text formatting (not just the background color)

IMO in most cases it would be ideal if it would copy just the semantic text formatting (bold, italitcs, formatted lists, etc...), but not any theme styling (background color, font color, font/font size, etc...). 

For example, similar to Typora's "Copy without theme styling" option (https://support.typora.io/Copy-and-Paste/), though I suppose that's more of a feature request than a bug
